text: The only thing that's worse than a channel or a tactic that you tried not working. The only thing that's worse now is when you didn't give it the appropriate shot, right? And you prematurely were erroneously concluded that it doesn't work and it's remarkable how often you find that to be the case when I talk to companies, "Oh, YouTube, we tried it. It doesn't work."
speaker: Yuriy Timen
context: Lenny and Yuriy are discussing common failure modes in growth strategy. Yuriy explains a major mistake he sees companies make when testing new growth channels and tactics. He emphasizes that many companies conclude a growth channel doesn't work without giving it a proper chance to succeed, which is actually worse than trying something that legitimately fails after adequate testing.
text_ko: 채널(channel)이나 전술(tactic)이 안 통하는 것만큼 안 좋은 건 없어요. 그런데 더 안 좋은 건 제대로 기회를 주지 않고 성급하게 '효과 없다'고 잘못 결론 내리는 거예요. 기업들 얘기를 들어보면 그런 경우가 정말 많더라고요. "유튜브요? 해봤는데 안 됐어요" 이렇게요.
text_zh: 有一件事比你试过的渠道或策略不奏效更糟糕。更糟糕的是，你根本没有给它足够的机会，对吧？你过早地就错误地下结论说它不行。我跟很多公司聊的时候，经常发现这种情况，特别常见。"哦，YouTube我们试过了，没用。"
text_es: Lo único que es peor que un canal o una táctica que probaste y no funcionó... lo único que es peor es cuando no le diste la oportunidad que merecía, ¿verdad? Y sacaste conclusiones apresuradas y equivocadas de que no sirve. Y es increíble qué tan seguido me encuentro con eso cuando hablo con empresas: "Ay, YouTube, ya lo probamos. No funciona."

text: I hard count my week at about three to three and a half days a week worth of work, which is a personal choice. And within that constraint, I also feel like for me to do my best work and the work that I also enjoy the most and find the most fulfilling four to five companies is probably the max. If I try to go beyond that, the overhead that it creates in terms of the cost of context switching just becomes overwhelming.
speaker: Yuriy Timen
context: Lenny asks Yuriy about his advising practice and how many companies he works with simultaneously. Yuriy explains his approach to managing his workload as a full-time advisor, describing how he deliberately limits both his working hours and number of clients to maintain quality. He discusses the concept of context switching costs - the mental overhead that comes from juggling too many different projects or clients at once.
text_ko: 저는 제 한 주를 대략 3~3.5일 분량의 일로 딱 제한해 놓고 있어요. 이건 개인적인 선택이에요. 그런 제약 안에서 제가 가장 잘할 수 있고 가장 즐겁고 보람을 느낄 수 있는 회사 수는 많아야 4~5곳인 것 같아요. 그걸 넘기면 문맥 전환(context switching) 비용 때문에 생기는 부담이 너무 커져서 감당이 안 돼요.
text_zh: 我仔细算了算，我一周大概就干三天到三天半的活儿，这是我个人的选择。在这个前提下，我觉得要想把工作做到最好，同时也是我最享受、最有成就感的状态，最多也就能同时管四到五家公司。如果再多的话，那种不断切换工作内容(context switching)带来的负担就太重了，根本受不了。
text_es: Calculando bien, yo trabajo unas tres a tres días y medio por semana, que es una decisión personal mía. Y dentro de esa limitación, también siento que para hacer mi mejor trabajo y el trabajo que más disfruto y me resulta más satisfactorio, cuatro o cinco empresas es probablemente lo máximo. Si trato de ir más allá de eso, la carga administrativa que crea en términos del costo del cambio de contexto (context switching) se vuelve abrumadora.

text: If you have really healthy LTVs, and that usually means that you're attracting a proconsumer buyer, so they may be single player, but they're using it for work. And so maybe they're dispensing it or just the perceived value so much higher that they're willing to bear that $120 and $130 a year subscription.
speaker: Yuriy Timen
context: Lenny asks Yuriy about different growth archetypes for consumer startups. Yuriy is explaining companies that can succeed with paid acquisition strategies. He describes 'proconsumer' products - those used by individual consumers but for professional purposes, which typically have higher lifetime values (LTVs) than typical consumer subscriptions. These higher LTVs make paid marketing more viable since companies can afford higher customer acquisition costs.
text_ko: 정말 고객 생애 가치(LTV)가 건전하다면, 보통 프로슈머(proconsumer) 고객을 끌어온다는 뜻이에요. 개인 사용자(single player)일 수 있지만 업무용으로 쓰는 경우가 많죠. 그래서 비용 처리(expensing)를 하거나, 단순히 체감 가치가 훨씬 높아서 연간 120~130달러짜리 구독료를 기꺼이 부담해요.
text_zh: 如果你的LTV(客户生命周期价值)真的很健康，那通常说明你吸引到的是专业消费者，他们可能是个人用户，但是用来工作的。所以可能他们会分摊费用，或者就是觉得价值很高，愿意承担每年120、130美元的订阅费用。
text_es: Si tienes LTVs realmente sanos, eso generalmente significa que estás atrayendo a un comprador "proconsumer" (proconsumer), o sea que tal vez sea un usuario individual, pero lo está usando para el trabajo. Entonces puede ser que lo esté distribuyendo o simplemente el valor percibido es mucho más alto y están dispuestos a pagar esa suscripción de $120 o $130 al año.

text: I think it's very difficult to manufacture. You'd only study when... It's very hard to manufacture product network effects if they aren't there from the get go. So Airbnb from your days, obviously marketplace very strong product network effect dynamics. You think of collaboration tools, Airtable, monday.com, Whimsical, whom we both know very strong inherent product network effects, contrast that with a company like Grammarly. It just wasn't there.
speaker: Yuriy Timen
context: Lenny asks about when companies should invest in virality and referral programs. Yuriy explains that product network effects - where the product becomes more valuable as more people use it - are usually inherent to the product from the beginning and very difficult to add later. He contrasts companies like Airbnb and collaboration tools that naturally have network effects with Grammarly, which is primarily a single-user writing tool where network effects don't naturally exist.
text_ko: 그건 인위적으로 만들어내기 굉장히 어렵다고 생각해요. 연구한다고 생기는 게 아니라, 처음부터 없던 프로덕트 네트워크 효과(product network effects)는 나중에 만들어내기 정말 힘들어요. 예를 들어 네가 있을 때의 에어비앤비는 마켓플레이스라서 프로덕트 네트워크 효과가 당연히 아주 강했죠. 협업 툴 쪽을 떠올리면 Airtable, monday.com, Whimsical 같은 서비스들은 우리 둘 다 알다시피 본질적으로 프로덕트 네트워크 효과가 강해요. 반면 Grammarly 같은 회사는 그런 게 그냥 없었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个很难人为制造出来。你只有在... 如果一开始就没有产品网络效应(product network effects)的话，后面想人为制造是非常困难的。像你那时候的Airbnb，很明显，marketplace模式天生就有很强的产品网络效应。再比如协作工具，像Airtable、monday.com、Whimsical这些我们都熟悉的公司，它们天生就有很强的产品网络效应，但你对比一下Grammarly这样的公司，它就是没有这种效应。
text_es: Creo que es muy difícil de crear artificialmente. Solo estudiarías cuando... Es súper complicado fabricar efectos de red del producto (product network effects) si no están ahí desde el primer día. Entonces Airbnb, de tu época, obviamente es un marketplace con dinámicas de efectos de red muy fuertes. Si piensas en herramientas de colaboración como Airtable, monday.com, Whimsical, que los dos conocemos, tienen efectos de red inherentes muy potentes. Contrasta eso con una empresa como Grammarly. Simplemente no los tenía.

text: I think SEO is pretty specialized skill set. There are some basic principles that always hold like best content wins and don't do shady back linking and make sure that you're on page. SEO is good and your pages are easily crawl, but I feel like everybody knows that. And where the winners are determined are between the lines.
speaker: Yuriy Timen
context: Lenny asks whether companies should work with SEO agencies or try to do SEO in-house. Yuriy explains that while basic SEO principles are well-known, success in SEO comes from more nuanced, specialized knowledge. He emphasizes that SEO requires staying current with algorithm changes and understanding subtle optimization techniques that differentiate successful companies from those that struggle with organic search.
text_ko: 저는 검색엔진최적화(SEO)가 꽤 전문적인 스킬셋이라고 생각해요. '좋은 콘텐츠가 이긴다' 같은 기본 원칙과 수상한 백링크(backlink)를 하지 말라는 것, 그리고 온페이지(on-page) 관리를 확실히 하라는 것들은 항상 유효해요. SEO를 잘하고 페이지가 크롤링(crawl)되기 쉽게 만드는 건 기본 중의 기본이고, 사실 다들 그 정도는 알고 있는 것 같아요. 진짜 승부는 결국 그 행간, 즉 작은 디테일들 사이에서 결정되는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得SEO是个很专业的技能。有些基本原则永远不会变，比如说好内容为王，别搞那些见不得人的反向链接(back linking)，还有确保你的页面SEO做得到位，让搜索引擎能轻松抓取(crawl)你的页面。不过我感觉这些大家都知道。真正拉开差距的，其实是那些细节上的功夫。
text_es: Creo que el SEO es una habilidad bastante especializada. Hay algunos principios básicos que siempre se mantienen como que el mejor contenido gana, no hacer enlaces sospechosos (shady back linking), y asegurarte de que tu SEO on-page esté bien y que tus páginas sean fáciles de rastrear (crawl). Pero siento que todo el mundo ya sabe eso. Y donde se determinan los ganadores es entre líneas.

text: I think in the short term paid acquisition and just paid media dollars are contracted and we're seeing it already with Metas advertising revenue, Snaps advertising revenue. There's clearly a global contraction happening to paid media budgets. A big part of it is because all of a sudden the definition of efficient acquisition and good payback windows is shifting.
speaker: Yuriy Timen
context: Lenny asks about how paid advertising effectiveness has changed recently due to market conditions and Apple's tracking changes. Yuriy explains that there's currently a global reduction in paid advertising spending, partly due to economic conditions and partly because companies are requiring much shorter payback periods - from 12 months down to 6 months or less. This has created a contraction in the paid media market as companies cut budgets that don't meet these stricter efficiency requirements.
text_ko: 단기적으로는 유료 획득(paid acquisition)과 유료 미디어(paid media) 지출이 벌써 줄어들고 있는 것 같아요. 메타(Meta)나 스냅(Snap)의 광고 수익에서 그 현상이 이미 보이고요. 확실히 전 세계적으로 유료 미디어 예산(paid media budgets)이 축소되고 있어요. 그 큰 이유 중 하나는 갑자기 효율적 획득(efficient acquisition)의 정의와 합리적인 투자 회수 기간(payback windows)에 대한 기준이 바뀌었기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得短期内付费获客(paid acquisition)和付费媒体(paid media)的预算都在收缩，这个趋势我们已经能从Meta和Snap的广告收入下滑看出来了。全球范围内付费媒体预算明显都在缩紧。很大一个原因是，突然间大家对什么叫高效获客、什么是合理的回本周期，这些标准都在变。
text_es: Creo que a corto plazo la adquisición pagada y el presupuesto de medios pagados se está contrayendo, y ya lo estamos viendo con los ingresos publicitarios de Meta y de Snap. Claramente hay una contracción global en los presupuestos de medios pagados. Gran parte se debe a que de repente está cambiando la definición de lo que es una adquisición eficiente y buenos períodos de retorno de inversión (payback windows).
